trial_identification.studytitle: Cannabis and Stroke Study (CASS): A comparison of positive drug screens for cannabis and amphetamines in stroke versus nonstroke patients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Study comparing the proportion of positive drug screens for cannabis and amphetamines in stroke and nonstroke patients aged between 45 and 55 years

interventions.interventions: Nonstroke patients aged 45- 55 years will have urine drug screen performed for cannabis and amphetamines. One urine sample drug screen at time of admisssion. Duration of study two years
interventions.comparator: Stroke patients aged 45 - 55 years from medical records 2009 to 2011

primaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of positive urine screens for cannabis and amphetamines in stroke and nonstroke patients
primaryOutcome.timepoint: one urine sample drug screen at time of admission

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: age 45- 55 years admission under general medicine with diagnosis other than stroke and a urine sample taken as part of their care

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Medicine University of Auckland Level 12, Support Building Auckland City Hospital 2 Park Road Grafton Auckland 1023

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Auckland City Hospital 2 Park Road Grafton Auckland 1023

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The hypothesis is that cannabis and amphetamine use can precipitate stroke. The Aim is to compare the proportion of positive urine drug screens of a group of young stroke patients with a group of nonstroke patients

contact.name: Heidi Pridmore
contact.address: Neurology Research Unit Department of Medicine Level 12, Support Building Auckland City Hospital 2 Park Road Grafton Auckland 1023
